case_name: Workmen v. M/s. Tata Locomotive Engineering Co., Ltd., Jamshedpur

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated 2nd March, 1959, of the Labour Court, Chotanagpur Division, Ranchi, in Misc. Cases Nos. 73,76, 77, 79-82, 84-90 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated 2nd March, 1959, of the Labour Court, Chotanagpur Division, Ranchi, in Misc. Cases Nos. 73,76, 77, 79-82, 84-90 of 1958.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J. on March 25, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. March 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-

facts.text: 14 appellants are workmen in M/s. Tata Locomotive Engineering Co., Ltd., Jamshedpur.

anchor.surface_text: The 14 appellants, all workmen in M s. Tata Locomotive Engineering Co., Ltd., Jamshedpur,

facts.text: The 14 appellants were dismissed under the orders of the company management on the result of an enquiry held against them.

anchor.surface_text: were dismissed under the orders of the companypanys management on the result of an enquiry held against them.

facts.text: Industrial disputes between these workmen and the company were pending before the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: As industrial disputes between these workmen and the companypany were at that time pending before the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar,

facts.text: Company filed applications under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act for approval of the action taken against the workmen.

anchor.surface_text: the companypany filed applications purporting to be under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act praying for approval of the action taken by it against the workmen.

facts.text: Workmen filed applications under s. 33A of the Industrial Disputes Act complaining of the action taken against them by the company.

anchor.surface_text: Workmen also filed applications under s. 33A of the Industrial Disputes Act companyplaining of the action taken against them by the companypany.

facts.text: Applications of the company under s. 33 were held to have become infructuous.

anchor.surface_text: The applications of the company- pany under s. 33 were however ultimately held to have become infructuous

facts.text: Labour Court dismissed the applications under s. 33A of these 14 appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The applications of these 14 appellants were however dismissed.

facts.text: Appellants obtained special leave for this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order the appellants have preferred this appeal after having obtained special leave for the purpose.

facts.text: On June 5, 1953, requests were made on behalf of the several workmen to be represented by a representative of the Jamshedpur Mazdoor Union at the enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that when on June 5, 1953, requests were made on behalf of the several workmen that they should be allowed to be represented by a representative of the Jamshedpur Mazdoor Union

facts.text: Management rejected the request for Union representation but allowed representation by a company worker from the workmen's own department.

anchor.surface_text: at the enquiry to companyduct the same on workmens behalf, the management rejected this request but informed the workmen that they companyld, if they so desired, be represented by a company worker from the workmens own department

facts.text: Court held that a workman has no right to be represented at the enquiry by a representative of his Union.

anchor.surface_text: Our companyclusion therefore is that a workman against whom an enquiry is being held by the management has numberright to be represented at such enquiry by a representative of his Union

facts.text: Charan Singh, Parmanand and K. Ganguli were accused of four acts: Participating in illegal strike, leaving place of duty, inciting strike, threatening workers.

anchor.surface_text: Each of these appellants it appears, was accused in the charge-sheet of four different acts of misconducts- Participating in an illegal strike Leaving your appointed place of duty Inciting other employees to strike work Threatening and intimidating other workers.

facts.text: Enquiry Officer found Charan Singh, Parmanand and K. Ganguli guilty of first three charges and also of 'Behaving in a riotous and disorderly manner by shouting slogans on the shop floor' not in charge-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: The Enquiry Officer found each of them guilty of the first three charges. He, however, recorded numberfindings as regards the fourth charge but instead found these workmen guilty of a misconduct number mentioned in the charge-sheet, viz., Behaving in a riotous and disorderly manner by shouting slogans on the shop floor .

facts.text: Manager would have dismissed Charan Singh, Parmanand and K. Ganguli even without the extra misconduct finding.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion that Necessarily follows is that leaving out of account the misconduct number mentioned in the charge-sheet, viz., behaving in a riotous and disorderly manner by shouting slogans in the shop floor , the manager would have made the order of dismissal.

facts.text: S. B. Nath accused of four acts: Participating in illegal strike, leaving place of duty, inciting strike, threatening workers.

anchor.surface_text: The charge-sheet against S. B. Nath accused him of four acts of misconduct- Participating in an illegal strike Leaving your appointed place of duty Inciting other employees to strike work Threatening and intimidating other workers.

facts.text: Dismissal order for S. B. Nath mentioned guilty of 'entering the works when not on duty and inciting other employees to strike work'.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of the order of dismissal is in these words- He has been found guilty of the following acts of misconduct- For entering the works when number on duty and inciting other employees to strike work.

facts.text: Court held that 'entering the works when not on duty' for S.B. Nath was description of manner of inciting, not separate misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that the statement in the dismissal order as regards entering the Works when number on duty was really intended to state the manner and occasion in which the misconduct of inciting other employees to strike work was companymitted.

facts.text: Gurbux Singh created a scene on 11th June, 1958, and left the place of enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: Though Mr. Gurubux Singh created a scene on the 11th June, 1958, and left the place of enquiry, still he was given a chance and the enquiry was held at a later date.

facts.text: Manager's order for Gurbux Singh dated with reference to charge-sheet date, dismissed him.

anchor.surface_text: The charges being of a very serious nature, I order that he be dismissed from the services of the companypany with effect from the date of the charge-sheet.

facts.text: Enquiry Officer's report had clerical error naming Charan Singh instead of Chakravarty for intimidation by Gurbux Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the Enquiry Officers report it is however obvious that there is a clerical error in the companycluding portion of the report in stating the finding as regards the fourth charge as threatening and intimidating Charan Singh to stop work .

facts.text: S. K. Dhanda found guilty by Enquiry Officer of three charges, not the fourth (threatening).

anchor.surface_text: The Enquiry Officers report states the companyclusions reached by him thus- From the statement of the witnesses, it has been companyclusively proved that Mr. Dhanda  1  participated in an illegal strike  2  left his place of duty without permission  3  incited other employees to stop work. It can be said that the charge of threatening and intimidating has number been proved beyond doubt.

facts.text: General Manager's order for S.K. Dhanda on July 3, 1958, noted fourth charge not proved but dismissed on other serious charges.

anchor.surface_text: I have gone through the findings of the Enquiry Officer and the proceedings of the enquiry. Even though the charge of threatening and intimidating other workers has number been proved against Mr. Dhanda the other charges are also of a serious nature. In the circumstances, order that he be dismissed from the service of the companypany with effect from the date of the charge-sheet. This was dated July 3, 1958,

facts.text: Formal dismissal order for S.K. Dhanda had clerical error including the unproved fourth charge.

anchor.surface_text: Reading the two together it is quite clear that the General Manager in passing the order of dismissal proceeded on the basis that the charge of threatening and intimidating other employees had number been proved against Mr. Dhanda but a mistake crept into the formal order that was drawn up

anchor.surface_text: When the general practice adopted by domestic tribunals is that the person accused companyducts his own case, we are unable to accept an argument that natural justice demands that in the case of enquiries into a chargesheet of misconduct against a workman he should be represented by a member of his Union.

concepts.interpretation: General practice in domestic tribunals is accused conducts own case; no demand for representation.

issues.text: When the management of an industry holds an enquiry into the charges against a workman for the purpose of deciding what action if any, should be taken against him, has the workman a right to be represented by a representative of his Union at the enquiry?

anchor.surface_text: When the management of an industry holds an enquiry into the charges against a workman for the purpose of deciding what action if any, should be taken against him, has the workman a right to be represented by a representative of his Union at the enquiry ?

issues.text: Whether the enquiry was not a proper and valid enquiry inasmuch as the workmen were not allowed to be represented at the enquiry by a representative of the Jamshedpur Union

anchor.surface_text: The main contention urged on behalf of the appellants was that the enquiry on the results of which the orders of dismissal were based was not a proper and valid enquiry inasmuch as the workmen were not allowed to be represented

issues.text: Whether the orders of dismissal were bad inasmuch as they were based on a finding of guilt of misconduct not mentioned in the charge-sheet

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants, Charan Singh, Parmanand and K. Ganguli, it was urged that the orders of dismissal were bad inasmuch as they were based on a finding of guilt of misconduct not mentioned in the charge-sheet.

issues.text: Whether the order of dismissal is bad as the appellant was not accused in the charge-sheet for entering the Works when not on duty but this had been taken into consideration in deciding on his punishment

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of the order of dismissal is in these words- He has been found guilty of the following acts of misconduct- For entering the works when not on duty and inciting other employees to strike work.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant M . R. Ghosh it was urged that the alleged misconduct of deliberately preventing the man in charge of the Compressor in the repair shop from carrying out his duty of which he is said to have been found guilty

issues.text: Whether the General Manager was misled by clerical error in the Enquiry Officer's report regarding threatening and intimidating Charan Singh instead of Mr. Chakravarty

anchor.surface_text: Though Mr. Gurubux Singh created a scene on the 11th June, 1958, and left the place of enquiry, still he was given a chance and the enquiry was held at a later date.

issues.text: Whether in making the dismissal order the General Manager wrongly thought that the appellant had been found guilty of all four acts of misconduct though the fourth charge was not proved

arguments.court_reasoning: Not a court of law; simple facts allow self-representation; general practice in domestic tribunals is accused conducts own case; natural justice does not demand union representation; validity challengeable in industrial adjudication

arguments.claim: Fair play demands reasonable assistance for examination and cross-examination of witnesses and proper recording; union representative best suited to provide such assistance; without it, workman does not get fair chance

anchor.surface_text: It has been urged that fair play demands that at such an enquiry the workman concerned should have reasonable assistance for examination and cross-examination of the witnesses and for seeing that proper records are made of the proceeding

arguments.court_reasoning: Accused workman often best to cross-examine; fair intelligence suffices for straightforward questioning; domestic tribunal rules do not provide for representation

arguments.claim: Workman has no right to be represented at management enquiry by union representative though employer may allow in discretion

anchor.surface_text: When the general practice adopted by domestic tribunals is that the person accused conducts his own case, we are unable to accept an argument that natural justice demands that in the case of enquiries into a chargesheet of misconduct against a workman he should be represented by a member of his Union.

arguments.claim: Finding on uncharged misconduct does not vitiate dismissal if punishing authority would have dismissed on proved charges alone

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion that necessarily follows is that leaving out of account the misconduct not mentioned in the charge-sheet, viz., behaving in a riotous and disorderly manner by shouting slogans in the shop floor, the manager would have made the order of dismissal.

arguments.claim: Clerical errors in naming or including unproved charges in reports or formal orders do not vitiate if punishing authority aware of actual findings and no prejudice caused

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the Enquiry Officers report it is however obvious that there is a clerical error in the concluding portion of the report in stating the finding as regards the fourth charge as threatening and intimidating Charan Singh to stop work.

holdings.text: a workman against whom an enquiry is being held by the management has no right to be represented at such enquiry by a representative of his Union though of course an employer in his discretion can and may allow his employee to avail himself of such assistance.

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion therefore is that a workman against whom an enquiry is being held by the management has no right to be represented at such enquiry by a representative of his Union though of course an employer in his discretion can and may allow his employee to avail himself of such assistance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Domestic enquiries are not courts of law; involve simple facts allowing self-representation; general practice in domestic tribunals is accused conducts own case; natural justice does not require union representation; can be challenged if otherwise unfair.

holdings.text: Refusal to allow union representation does not vitiate the enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The common contention urged on behalf of the appellants was that the enquiry on the results of which the orders of dismissal were based was not a proper and valid enquiry inasmuch as the workmen were not allowed to be represented at the enquiry by a representative of the Jamshedpur Union to which these workmen belonged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry fair otherwise; workman can conduct own case or use co-worker; no prejudice shown.

holdings.text: leaving out of account the misconduct not mentioned in the charge-sheet, viz., behaving in a riotous and disorderly manner by shouting slogans in the shop floor, the manager would have made the order of dismissal. The fact that this act of misconduct not mentioned in the charge-sheet was also mentioned as one of the items on which the order of dismissal was based does not therefore affect the validity of the order.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion that necessarily follows is that leaving out of account the misconduct not mentioned in the charge-sheet, viz., behaving in a riotous and disorderly manner by shouting slogans in the shop floor , the manager would have made the order of dismissal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Punishing authority imposed same punishment in similar cases on proved charges alone; no reason to discriminate.

holdings.text: the statement in the dismissal order as regards entering the Works when not on duty was really intended to state the manner and occasion in which the misconduct of inciting other employees to strike work was committed... The contention that the mention in the dismissal order of entering the Works when not on duty as an act of misconduct of which he had been found guilty, vitiates the order of dismissal cannot therefore be accepted.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that the statement in the dismissal order as regards entering the Works when not on duty was really intended to state the manner and occasion in which the misconduct of inciting other employees to strike work was committed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not a separate misconduct under standing orders; merely describes how incitement occurred; did not influence punishment.

holdings.text: The statement in the dismissal order as regards his being guilty of deliberately preventing the man in charge of the Compressor in the Repair Shop from carrying out his duty has in fact been mentioned in the charge-sheet, though in slightly different words. There is no substance therefore, in the contention that the acts of misconduct on which the dismissal order was based included one not mentioned in the charge-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: This is obviously erroneous. The charge-sheet after alleging the four acts of misconduct went on to give particulars of these charges. As regards the fourth charge, viz., threatening and intimidating the other workers in the Repair Shop the particulars were in- these words By threatening and intimidating others in the repair shop you stopped them from working and also you took the Compressor man by his hand and got the Compressor stopped.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act described in particulars of fourth charge (threatening); not new misconduct.

holdings.text: there is a clerical error in the concluding portion of the report... It is reasonable to think that that conclusion and not the wrong statement that Charan Singh was threatened and intimidated which was nobody's case weighed with the General Manager in determining the punishment. In our opinion, there is no substance in the contention...

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the Enquiry Officers report it is however obvious that there is a clerical error in the concluding portion of the report in stating the finding as regards the fourth charge as threatening and intimidating Charan Singh to stop work .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obvious clerical mistake (name error); body of report and evidence show correct finding on Chakravarty; irrelevant to general charge; punishing authority reviewed evidence, not misled.

holdings.text: It is proper to hold that this was an accidental clerical mistake and that in fact the General Manager did not proceed on the wrong basis that Dhanda had been found guilty on this fourth charge also. The mere fact that such a clerical error appears in the formal order does not affect the validity of the order in any way.

anchor.surface_text: Reading the two together it is quite clear that the General Manager in passing the order of dismissal proceeded on the basis that the charge of threatening and intimidating other employees had not been proved against Mr. Dhanda but a mistake crept into the formal order that was drawn up

holdings.reasoning_summary: GM's order on report explicitly notes fourth charge not proved but others sufficient; formal order mistake accidental; substance shows correct basis.

holdings.text: We have therefore come to the conclusion that the separate contentions pressed on behalf of seven of the appellants that the Tribunals below did not consider certain infirmities in the order cannot also be sustained.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All specific challenges to enquiry validity and dismissal orders rejected; Labour Court correctly dismissed s.33A applications.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Clerical Error in Enquiry Report or Order support
Clerical Error in Enquiry Report or Order support

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore come to the conclusion that the separate contentions pressed on behalf of seven of the appellants that the Tribunals below did not consider certain infirmities in the order cannot also be sustained.

outcome.relief_summary: All contentions of the appellants regarding invalidity of domestic enquiry and infirmities in dismissal orders rejected; Labour Court order dismissing s.33A applications upheld

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion therefore is that a workman against whom an enquiry is being held by the management has no right to be represented at such enquiry by a representative of his Union though of course an employer in his discretion can and may allow his employee to avail himself of such assistance.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the separate contentions pressed on behalf of seven of the appellants that the Tribunals below did not consider certain infirmities in the order cannot also be sustained.
the workman companycerned should have reasonable assistance for examination and cross-examination of the witnesses and for seeing that proper records

edges.explanation: Holding h2 that refusal to allow union rep does not vitiate addresses issue i2

anchor.surface_text: The common contention urged on behalf of the appellants was that the enquiry on the results of which the orders of dismissal were based was not a proper and valid enquiry inasmuch as the workmen were not allowed to be represented at the enquiry by a representative of the Jamshedpur Union to which these workmen belonged.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the separate contentions pressed on behalf of seven of the appellants that the Tribunals below did not consider certain infirmities in the order cannot also be sustained.

edges.explanation: h3 addresses i3 by confirming dismissal valid even without the uncharged misconduct finding

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion that necessarily follows is that leaving out of account the misconduct not mentioned in the charge-sheet, viz., behaving in a riotous and disorderly manner by shouting slogans in the shop floor , the manager would have made the order of dismissal.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the separate contentions pressed on behalf of seven of the appellants that the Tribunals below did not consider certain infirmities in the order cannot also be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that the statement in the dismissal order as regards entering the Works when not on duty was really intended to state the manner and occasion in which the misconduct of inciting other employees to strike work was committed.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the separate contentions pressed on behalf of seven of the appellants that the Tribunals below did not consider certain infirmities in the order cannot also be sustained.

edges.explanation: h5 addresses i5 by contextualizing the compressor prevention statement within charged misconduct

anchor.surface_text: This is obviously erroneous. The charge-sheet after alleging the four acts of misconduct went on to give particulars of these charges. As regards the fourth charge, viz., threatening and intimidating the other workers in the Repair Shop the particulars were in- these words By threatening and intimidating others in the repair shop you stopped them from working and also you took the Compressor man by his hand and got the Compressor stopped.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the separate contentions pressed on behalf of seven of the appellants that the Tribunals below did not consider certain infirmities in the order cannot also be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the Enquiry Officers report it is however obvious that there is a clerical error in the concluding portion of the report in stating the finding as regards the fourth charge as threatening and intimidating Charan Singh to stop work .

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the separate contentions pressed on behalf of seven of the appellants that the Tribunals below did not consider certain infirmities in the order cannot also be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: Reading the two together it is quite clear that the General Manager in passing the order of dismissal proceeded on the basis that the charge of threatening and intimidating other employees had not been proved against Mr. Dhanda but a mistake crept into the formal order that was drawn up

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the separate contentions pressed on behalf of seven of the appellants that the Tribunals below did not consider certain infirmities in the order cannot also be sustained.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the separate contentions pressed on behalf of seven of the appellants that the Tribunals below did not consider certain infirmities in the order cannot also be sustained.
